text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Israeli newspapers on Thursday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
JERUSALEM POST
- Prime minister cancels U.S. trip to oversee completion of Hebron redeployment deal. Hebron awaits day after redeployment with trepidation.
- Trade Minister Natan Sharansky: Arrest of Israeli mechanic in Egypt a plot to undermine Jewish state. Israel: Azam Azam is no agent.

- Czech corporation Skoda seeks to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in the Middle East, with Israel high on the list of preferred countries. Company is keen to help Israel Electric Corporation and any other government company due for privatisation.
- Diamond merchant Lev Leviev, 40, says he based decision to buy controlling share in Africa Israel Investments on expectations the real estate market will recover in near future from slowdown.
- Council of Jewish Federations in U.S. expected to urge no change in Jewish conversion legislation.
- Shas spiritual leader Rabbi Ovadia Yosef to encourage kidney donations.
- Albert Einstein in letter to wife: "Do exactly as I say."
GLOBES
- Improvement in building sector: Rise of 13.3 percent in purchase of apartments in October.
- Recovery plan for Scitex: Split of graphic arts; dozens of offices will be closed.
HAARETZ
- Palestinian police gather weapons of Hamas people in Hebron ahead of evacuation. U.S. Middle East peace envoy Dennis Ross leaves for Israel.
- "It's permissible to carry out action that causes death, in the way the sacred Dr Baruch Goldstein did in Hebron," says rabbi in reference to Jewish settler who massacred 29 Arabs.
MAARIV
- Israeli army conducts exercise with re-enforcements -- ahead of Hebron evacuation.
YEDIOTH AHRONOTH
- Israeli army will redeploy in Hebron next week, a very senior official expects. The last battle: Palestinian demand for preconfirmation of "hot pursuit" after terrorists.
- About half of all television owners evade licence fees.
